StringWithMarkup.String: In Canada, 6.6% of 881 pork liver samples contained pentachlorophenol at concns >0.1 mg/kg, max concn = 0.72 mg/kg(1). 2% of 51 beef liver samples contained pentachlorophenol at concns >0.1 mg/kg, max concn = 0.35 mg/kg. Only one sample out of 214 chicken and 68 turkey liver samples contained pentachlorophenol at a concn >0.1 mg/kg(1). In the state of Michigan pentachlorophenol has been reported in dairy cattle housed in a pentachlorophenol-treated barn and feed bins at a range of 58-1136 ppb(2). Detected concns in adipose tissue of beef cattle ranged from 5,378-13,653 pg/g in steers with an exposure known to be due solely to pentachlorophenol-treated wood in wooden pens at the Carrington Research Extension Center, Carrington, North Dakota(3). Concns ranged from 542-1,581,331 pg/g in adipose tissue of beef cattle of which less was known regarding exposure(3).

Reference: (1) Zitko V et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 12: 649-53 (1974)
(2) Elliott JE, Martin PA; Environ Monit Assess 53: 337-62 (1998)

StringWithMarkup.String: Pentachlorophenol has been reported in bird eggs at 0.36 (double-crested cormorant from White Horse, Bay of Fundy) and 0.51 ppb (herring gull,  Hospital Island, Passamaquoddy Bay), collected in spring, 1973(1). Grebes and seaducks along coastal British Columbia, Canada were sampled between 1991 and 1992(2). Pentachlorophenol was detected at 0.6 ug/kg wet weight in Western Grebe breast tissue, 0.6 and 0.9 ug/kg wet weight in Common Merganser breast and liver tissue, 4.3 ug/kg wet weight in Lesser Scaup breast tissue, 4.5 ug/kg in Common Goldeneye breast tissue, and 2.8 and 1.3 ug/kg wet weight in Bufflehead breast and liver tissue(2).

StringWithMarkup.String: One of three new cotton T-shirt samples purchased in Bayreuth, Germany, tested for the presence of pentachlorophenol, contained this compound at 2000 ng/g (detection limit = 10 ng/g)(1). Mean concentrations of pentachlorophenol in samples from nine homes in Raleigh, Durham and Chapel Hill, NC were reported as 0.48 ug/sq m, 0.03 ug/sq m, 0.02 ug/sq m, 0.02 ug, 0.05 ug/cu m, 0.03 ug/g, 0.02 ug/g, and 0.02 ug/g for house dust, PUF roller (carpet dust), investigator hand, child hand rinse, air, entryway soil, walkway soil, and play area soil, respectively(2). Pentachlorophenol was measured in raw wood (3 of 15 samples positive; 0.25 mg/kg max), wood packings and pallets (3 of 39 samples positive; 0.90 mg/kg max), interior decoration (21 of 30 samples positive; 11.6 mg/kg max), beams (4 of 22 samples positive; 0.32 mg/kg max), windows (64 of 68 samples positive; 163.3 mg/kg max), fences and stakes (13 of 14 samples positive; 0.70 mg/kg max), cable-drums (4 of 10 samples positive; 1.32 mg/kg max), and recycling chips (8 of 9 samples positive; 4.43 mg/kg max), waste wood originated from the countries of Argentina, Germany, India, Italy, Spain and others not listed(3).

StringWithMarkup.String: NIOSH (NOES Survey 1981-1983) has statistically estimated that 26,806 workers (4,191 of these were female) were potentially exposed to pentachlorophenol in the US(1). The NOES Survey does not include farm workers. Occupational exposure to pentachlorophenol may occur via dermal contact, primarily in situations where workers use this compound as a preservative or are in contact with treated wood products. Monitoring data indicate that the general population may be exposed to pentachlorophenol via inhalation of ambient air, ingestion of food and drinking water, and dermal contact with this compound(SRC).

Reference: (1) IARC; Monographs on the Evaluation of the Carcinogenic Risk of Chemicals to Man. Geneva: World Health Organization, International Agency for Research on Cancer, 1972-PRESENT. (Multivolume work). Some Halogenated Hydrocarbons 20: 303-25 (1979)

StringWithMarkup.String: The major occupational exposure is to workers in the lumber and wood products industry(1). Air and urine samples taken at 25 factories using pentachlorophenol as a wood preservative showed that the average worker's exposure in air was 0.013 mg/cu m(1). Elevated levels were found in workers' urine and serum(1). Aerial spraying of farm crops gave rise to levels of pentachlorophenol of 0.9 mg/cu m in the cockpit of the spray plane, 38 mg/cu m in the vicinity of the signal man and 1-4 mg/cu m outside the treated field(2). At a sawmill in Finland, urine from exposed workers contained pentachlorophenol at concns from not detected to 15.9 ng/mg creatinine(3).

StringWithMarkup.String: The long-term, avg daily intake of pentachlorophenol is estimated to be 16 ug/day(1).

Reference: (1) Duggan RE et al; Pesticide Residue Levels in Foods in the US, FDA and Assoc Off Anal Chem p. 5 (1983)

StringWithMarkup.String: US daily intake - % pos (ug): 1971 - 0.6% (0.03 ug), 1972-0, 1973 - 2.5% (0.7 ug), 1974 - 3.0% (0.8 ug), 1975 - 5.4% (2.0 ug), 1976 - 0.8% (1.0 ug)(1). Results from the US FDA's Adult Total Diet Study in which the typical 14-day diet of a 16-19 yr male was collected throughout the US from market basket composite samples in 12 food groups (Fiscal Year-average intake (ug/kg body wt/day)) are: FY79 0.006, FY 80 0.040, FY 81/82 0.052(2). An analogous study for infants and toddlers calculated that in FY 81/82, that daily pentachlorophenol input per unit body weight was 0.023 and 0.079 ug/kg, respectively(2). In the 1988 Total Diet Study, the intake of pentachlorophenol in ug/kg body wt/day was 0.0004, 0.0002, and 0.0003 for a 6-11 month old, 14-16 yr male, and 60-65 yr female, respectively(3). For the FY 81/82 Adult Total Diet Survey, 27 cities were sampled. In FY 81/82, there were 48 positive samples out of the 27 composites from each of the 12 food groups containing pentachlorophenol levels up to 0.024 ppm(2). The avg 70 kg man would have an avg intake of 3.62 ug/day(2). Mean daily intake of pentachlorophenol from 1984-1986, determined during the FDA's Total Diet Study, was reported as 0.0169. 0.0379, 0.0135, 0.0183, 0.0130, 0.0156, 0.0108, and 0.0127 ug/kg body weight/day for a 6- 11 month old child, a 2 year old child, a 14-16 year old female, a 14-16 year old male, a 25-30 year old female, a 25-30 year old male, a 60-65 year old female and a 60-65 year old male, respectively(4). Intake of pentachlorophenol found in the Total Diet Study analyses for 1986 to 1991 were reported as 0.0009, 0.0014, 0.0005, 0.0008, and 0.0007 ug/kg body weight/day for a 6-11 month old child, a 2 year old child, a 14-16 year old male and female, a 25-30 year old female and a 60-65 year old male and female, and a 25-30 year old male, respectively(4).

StringWithMarkup.String: Level of 15 ppb(1), 10-120 ppb in blood from users of pentachlorophenol-contaminated water were reported(2). Serum of 123 residents of pentachlorophenol-treated log homes ranged from 69-1340 ppb, 420 ppb mean, while 34 controls ranged from 15-75 ppb, 40 ppb(3). Serum levels in 25 occupationally-exposed workers in 5 workplaces ranged from 26 to 84,900 ppb(3). Medium serum pentachlorophenol levels in 4 of the workplaces ranged from 83 to 490 ppb, while in the chemical packaging area of a chemical plant it was 62,000 ppb(3). Avg serum concn (of pentachlorophenol) of 7 workers continuously exposed to chlorophenols at 2 saw mills was 0.84-0.85 ppm(4). Concns of pentachlorophenol in the blood serum and urine of workers involved either with the production of pentachlorophenol or with the treatment of wood with pentachlorophenol have been measured(5). Urine of workers responsible for lumber dipping, spraying or brushing contained pentachlorophenol at mean concns from 1.31 to 2.83 mg/L (blood serum mean = 5.14 mg/L); urine from an individual in the office at a lumber yard contained 0.06 mg/L pentachlorophenol (blood serum mean = 0.65 mg/L). Individuals involved with pentachlorophenol production had mean blood serum and urine levels of 0.72-2.38 mg/L and 4.73 mg/L, respectively(5). Adipose tissue from 58 people (not occupationally exposed) from southern and northern Finland contained pentachlorophenol at a median concn of 0.002 ug/g residue fat; 75-81.8% of the samples were positive(6). 84.6% of the liver samples were positive for pentachlorophenol with a median concn of 0.004 ug/g(6).

StringWithMarkup.String: Urine of 118 residents of pentachlorophenol-treated log homes ranged from 1-340 ppb, 69 ppb mean, while 143 controls ranged from 1-7 ppb, mean 3.4 ppb(1). All urine samples from 197 Arkansas children contained pentachlorophenol(2). The median and max pentachlorophenol concn was 14 and 240 ppb. All 87 urine samples collected randomly in Saskatchewan, Canada, contained pentachlorophenol at concentrations from 0.5 to 9.1 ng/mL (detection limit = 0.2 ng/mL; avg = 1.6 ng/mL and median = 1.3 ng/mL)(3). A second study of 38 urine samples from "normal, healthy" humans living in Saskatchewan, Canada, reported pentachlorophenol concentrations from 0.1 to 3.6 ng/mL with an average concentration of 0.9 ng/mL and a median concentration of 0.5 ng/mL(3). Levels in samples of seminal fluid obtained from volunteer Florida State University students have been reported as 100-200 ppb(4) and in adipose tissue obtained from autopsy samples from the University of Florida at 250-500 ppb(4) and 23 ppb in autopsy samples taken in 10 women from Dade County, FL(5). The mean levels of pentachlorophenol in samples collected from the general population in Barcelona, Spain, in 1982-83 were 25 ng/mL (50 samples) in urine and 21.9 ng/mL (100 samples) in serum(6).

Reference: (1) Geno PW et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 30: 132-38 (1996)
(2) Wagner SL et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 21: 596-606 (1991)

StringWithMarkup.String: Pentachlorophenol was detected during hand wipe studies of 5 children living on 3 different farms; concns ranged from 9 to 99 ng(1). The National Human Monitoring Program for Pesticides, USEPA, has shown that approximately 85% of all human urine samples contain pentachlorophenol at a mean of 0.0063 ppm and a max of 0.193 ppm(2). Avg concns of pentachlorophenol in tissue samples obtained from 8 humans from western Oregon were as follows: testis, 1.087 ppm; kidney, 0.953 ppm; prostate, 0.838 ppm; liver, 0.592 ppm; omentum fat, 0.029 ppm; subcutaneous fat, 0.017 ppm; perinephric fat, 0.016 ppm(2).

Reference: (1) Cline RE et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 18: 475-81 (1989)

StringWithMarkup.String: A study of serum and urine pentachlorophenol concentrations in persons living in log homes and workers occupationally exposed to pentachlorophenol was conducted. The study group consisted of 35 persons exposed to pentachlorophenol in six workplaces and 123 persons living in 45 homes constructed of pentachlorophenol treated logs. The comparisons consisted of 143 persons living in conventional homes and not occupationally exposed to pentachlorophenol. Urine and blood samples were collected and analyzed for pentachlorophenol. Among the comparisons, urine pentachlorophenol concentrations ranged from 1 to 17 ppb, mean 3.4 ppb. Serum samples from 34 comparisons ranged from 15 to 75 ppb, mean 40 ppb. In persons living in pentachlorophenol treated log homes, serum pentachlorophenol concentrations ranged from 69 to 1340 ppb, mean 420 ppb. The serum pentachlorophenol concns decreased with increasing age. Subjects in the 2 to 7 year old group had significantly higher serum pentachlorophenol concns than those over 15 years old. The serum pentachlorophenol concentrations in children 2 to 15 years old averaged 1.7 to 2.0 times that of their parents. Repeat blood samples taken from ten persons residing in homes in which the logs were coated with a sealant showed that sealing the logs resulted in decreased serum pentachlorophenol concentrations. Urine pentachlorophenol concns ranged from 1 to 340 ppb, mean 69 ppb. When the urine pentachlorophenol concns were corrected for creatinine concns, they correlated well with the serum pentachlorophenol concns. Serum pentachlorophenol concentrations in the pentachlorophenol workers ranged from 26 to 84900 ppb. The lowest concentrations occurred in workers constructing homes from pentachlorophenol treated logs and the highest in workers exposed to pentachlorophenol in chemical factories. Urine pentachlorophenol concentrations in four workers ranged from 2400 to 13800 ppb, mean 10000 ppb(1).

Reference: (1) Noren K, Meironyte D; Chemosphere 40: 1111-123 (2000)
(2) Noren K; Sci Total Environ 139/140: 347-55 1993)
(3) Meironyteguvenius D et al; Environ Health Perspect 111: 1235-1241 (2003)
(4) Gebefugi I, Korte F; Chemosphere 12: 1055-60 (1983)
(5) Meijer L et al;; Environ Sci Technol 42: 3428-33 (2008)

StringWithMarkup.String: A mean concn of 12 ng/g pentachlorophenol was detected in Swedish human milk samples between 1984 and 1985(1). Milk from 10 to 20 Swedish women, from 1972 to 1989, contained pentachlorophenol at 0.0125 to 0.036 ug/g fat(2). Pentachlorophenol was detected at a median concn of 2 pg/g, ranging from 10-570 pg/g, in 15 Swedish mothers between 2000 and 2001(3). Bavaria, Germany - 0.03-2.83 ppb - 21 donors(4). Pentachlorophenol concentration in 90 maternal serum samples from The Netherlands ranged from 300 to 8500 pg/g serum, fresh weight basis, with a median concentration of 970 pg/g. The concentration in chord serum was 420 to 1900 pg/g serum, fresh weight basis, with a median concentration of 1500 pg/g serum(5).

Literature references related to scientific contents from Springer Nature journals and books. It is based on: (1) the TF-IDF, adapted to chemical structures, (2) location information in the text (e.g. title, abstract, keywords), and (3) the document size.  Springer Nature aims to provide only highly qualitative and relevant content but references of lower relevance aren't withheld as they might contain also very useful information.

Reference.Description: The USGS Health-Based Screening Levels for Evaluating Water-Quality Data contains Health-Based Screening Levels (HBSLs) that are non-enforceable water-quality benchmarks that can be used to (1) supplement U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) Maximum Contaminant Levels (MCLs) and Human Health Benchmarks for Pesticides (HHBPs), (2) determine whether contaminants found in surface-water or groundwater sources of drinking water may indicate a potential human-health concern, and (3) help prioritize monitoring efforts. HBSLs were developed by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS).

Reference.Name: GHS Classification Tree
Reference.Description: The United Nations' Globally Harmonized System of Classification and Labeling of Chemicals (GHS) provides a harmonized basis for globally uniform physical, environmental, and health and safety information on hazardous chemical substances and mixtures. It sets up criteria for the classification of chemicals for physical-chemical, health, and environmental hazards of chemical substances and mixtures and sets up standardized hazard information to facilitate global trade of chemicals.  Please note that obsolete codes are added in this classification for completeness purposes, as they are still in use. Any obsolete codes are annotated as such.

Reference.Name: EPA SRS List Classification
Reference.Description: Substance Registry Services (SRS) is the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) central system for information about substances that are tracked or regulated by EPA or other sources. It is a resource for basic information about chemicals, biological organisms, and other substances of interest to EPA and its state and tribal partners. SRS makes it possible to identify which EPA data systems, environmental statutes, or other sources have information about a substance and which synonym is used by that system or statute.

Reference.Name: EPA TSCA Classification
Reference.Description:
EPA Chemicals under the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA) collection contains information on chemicals and their regulation under TSCA. The chemical classification tree is created based on the TSCA substance regulatory flag, UVCB, and commercial activity status.
Update: 2024-12-06 12:51:01

Reference.Name: MolGenie Organic Chemistry Ontology
Reference.Description: An organic chemistry ontology developed by MolGenie and OntoChem to assign chemical entities to structural classes, split into three main subsections: calculated properties, compounds and substructural concepts. The ontology contains chemistry structural classes with a focus on elements and small organic compounds, but not inorganic, polymer, biopolymer, metal complexes, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and other chemistry entities. The ontology has been mapped to several collections of chemicals, including (a) Chemicals of Biological Interest (ChEBI), (b) the ChEMBL database of bioactive molecules, (c) the LOTUS natural product collection, (d) per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) extracted from Barnabas et al (2022) DOI: 10.1039/D2DD00019A (e) PubChemLite and (f) the ZeroPM Global Chemical Inventory.
Reference.LicenseNote: CC-BY 4.0

Reference.Name: SID 403031940
Reference.Description: The PATENTSCOPE database from WIPO includes patent and chemical structure search (with a free account) that gives access to millions of patent documents. The World Intellectual Property Organisation (WIPO) is a specialized United Nations (UN) agency headquartered in Geneva (Switzerland). Our mission is to lead the development of a balanced and effective international Intellectual Property (IP) system that enables innovation and creativity for the benefit of all. We help governments, businesses and society realize the benefits of Intellectual Property and are notably a world reference source for IP information.
LinkOut is a service that allows one to link directly from NCBI databases to a wide range of information and services beyond NCBI systems.
